column4: Has anyone found a workaround for the problem where Ubuntu fails to boot because it's waiting for root device and it drops to busybox? I'm dual booting and I have to start Windows to get rid of it.
what filesystem are you using with your install?
ext3
do you have an ocz ssd? they have an awesome time loss glitch
so it never finds the root filesystem?
Nope doesn't matter if you leave it on all night and type exit still won't start
you can look at dmesg and for the actual partition from that busybox prompt
if it hits that shell it's never going to recover automatically
That's a good idea I hadn't thought of that.
beyond that, is this an upgrade from older versions? or have you edited fstab
well it's not one problem, and people can do thousands of things to their linux install to make it happen
True, It seems mostly to be either you didn't wait long enough for the root device or there seems to be some mysterious other reason no one's worked out yet.
people give up, you can at least gather more information
as long as the uuid is specified for the root filesystem, and correct; it should find it barring other problems not related to strictly mounting it

When I get around to working on this again I think that's the avenue I'm going to approach it from. I feel like it's an issue of it not getting mounted properly. If I come up with a fix I'll put it on the forums.
find the problem, it'll probably be different from what other people have to deal with; only the symptoms might resemble eachother

Na this computer has been 10.10 from the get go. I get the feeling that like I said before there are two problem here. One fixed by increasing root delay and another having to do with the windows partition. I would be surprised if it were different problems. Everyone says the same thing and that it is fixed by starting windows and then restarting into ubuntu.
well on the laptop, i could suggest some things if i knew the chipset being used
but with the ocz ssd unless you've ruled out the time warp thing i can't offer anything, cuz it's the exact same symptoms and "solution"
I really appreciate it but I've got to go back to work lol I've spent way too long trying to figure this one out lol
agh you shouldn't heh; it has its own sudo wrapper, for building the modules; and that's the only phase that needs root
Huh never knew that I've always just had to run it as sudo. I just edited the menu and added the line gksudo in front of it.
